job_title: Teacher in Newcastle, England
pros: nothing to mention, as the job is not good
cons: bad in area, and location and salary

job_title: Lecturer in Newcastle, England
pros: Teaching disadvantaged kids is really rewarding when you get it right and the vast majority of students are lovely and hardworking people. There is a free gym and a nice bistro on site run by students.
cons: Staff are VERY cliquey, and there is sadly a lot of bullying at Newcastle College. Morale is very low and teachers feel overworked and stressed. A lot of examples of management and senior management being hired on the basis of cronyism or nepotism. Most teachers will have at least one story of gross misconduct about their manager, however this never seems to be actioned. There is a big "blame culture" atmosphere at NCG and sadly this means that new staff are very frequently subjected to unfair disciplinary treatment, ultimately leaving as a result of this. HR are very much on the management side and are distressingly opaque, sometimes even refusing to communicate with unions. A really awful place to work.

job_title: Maintenance in Newcastle under Lyme, England
pros: Extra holiday at Christmas time
cons: Awful place to work, bully culture among the staff which comes from senior management. Sneaky two-faced HR and salary is low with no pay rises

job_title: Work Experience Consultant in Newcastle, England
pros: This is a really good place to work in terms of equality and diversity. The standards of teaching and delivery are very high and we are proud of our connections to local industries. Staff are treated with respect for the most part and if you are a hard worker, this is the place for you.
cons: Long hours can be poor for mental health.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Pay is on par with other educational establishments.
cons: Terrible management and poor staff support. Bogged down with unnecessary paperwork and being directed by managers who cannot teach.

job_title: Learning Support Practitioner in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Helpful team
Members always on hand
cons: Hr can be poor and no reply

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Friendly teachers
Good mechanical equipment
Well managed
cons: Computers are very old and slow

job_title: Programmer Leader in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Generally well supported. Good camaraderie within team. Good level of autonomy over programme area.
cons: Tonnes of admin. Teaching expectations in terms of hours is massive (24 per week as a minimum, usually more than this) with limited time for self-development, prep etc. Salary bandings lower than typical for role type when compared to university roles. IT and infrastructure sorely needs updating and investment. As a subsidiary to a larger parent group (NCG), there can sometimes be mixed messages in expectations.

job_title: Executive in Newcastle, England
pros:
Puts the student first 
Passionate about its contribution to development 
Supportive environment 
Really great office 
Early finish on Friday
cons:
Can be quite disjointed between teams 
Sharing information and collaboration isn’t easy

review_title: Enthusiastic, pro-active? Don't worry we'll soon knock that out of you
job_title: Administrator in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Like a lot of public sector organisations - holiday entitlement is great, you get lots. Pay grades are very clear and precise.
cons: There seems to be a bit of an 'old-school' set of people, who are very behind the times in terms of skills and attitudes (sexism, racism and almost every other -ism) who for whatever reason haven't been removed from post. Processes are really behind the times - everything from HR to day-to-day working methods.

job_title: Administrative Manager in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
30 days holiday allowance  (+ 8 BH) can be more through additional working (time owing)
Great teams
Mostly supportive environment
Family friendly/flexible working
Varied work/tasks
Busy so the time flies
cons:
Huge workloads
Sometimes unrealistic deadlines
Some unnecessary processes generate work
Sometimes very short notice of requirement to work late at times due to late submissions from other depts
pick up work from other depts rather than returning the work and training the dept to submit correctly
Flexible remit as opposed to other depts often additional work is passed to admin
Parking is horrendous

review_title: Play the game to do well here
job_title: Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great staff at the coal face, lots of camaraderie, lots of contacts to make. A great place to cut your teeth as a FE teacher. If you know which battles to pick you can have an ok time there.
cons: Management is often shambolic, organisation is shambolic, greater and greater workloads (but this is teaching). Lots of knee jerk decisions. I have heard some allegations of nepotism and racism in recruitment.

review_title: Company growth without the necessary culture and remuneration change to reflect the transition

review_title: Awful, top down management practices at it worst!!!!
job_title: Program Leader in Newcastle, England
pros: There's a lot of good reasons to work there - but the heavy handed management practices fails to allow thinking out of the box. As well as pitching colleges against one-another!
cons:
Avoiding the "power" of the management to make your life hell.
Even the Unions do not rate this college, due to its dreadful management practices.

Do a search on YouTube for some excellent videos, including a BBC 1 News review from 2011 - draw your own conclusions.

Invisible management in HE
Lack of focus or direction
